results.content: Although modifying human zygotes and implanting them to generate humans perhaps has insurmountable safety and ethical limitations, the use of editing as a research tool to understand early human development or disease pathogenesis and treatment without implantation is probably ethically permissible based on current guidelines (for examples, see National Institutes of Health [NIH] ) The major ethical issue for the research use of editing in human zygotes is that it would require the specific generation of 1-cell zygotes for study as zygotes generated by in vitro fertilization are already at the multicellular blastocyst stage and thus beyond the very earliest stages of zygote development Moreover, at the multicellular blastocyst stage, any editing approach would likely create a mosaic of edited cells in which different cells acquired different genomic changes, thus confounding any experimental results
